awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Application of Microscopy and Microanalysis in Multidisciplinary Research
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site continues its operation to enable undergraduate students to gain multidisciplinary research experience. This site has been successfully operating for the past eighteen years and has achieved a high level of participation from women, minorities, and student veterans of the US Armed Forces. This REU site unites undergraduates from different disciplines, ethnic backgrounds, and institutions, and provides hands-on research experiences to assist them in pursuing careers in science and engineering. This renewal project broadens impact by including nontraditional students (who have a delay after high school graduation before starting their college education). 

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The REU site ties diverse research projects together under the overarching theme of electron microscopy for multidisciplinary applications. Through a concentrated summer program, the participants obtain technical training, conduct independent research, visit local high-tech industries, and present their research at an REU symposium. The activities begin with a training week including workshops on laboratory safety, library database searches, and graduate school applications. Students are offered an intensive short course in using scanning electron microscope or focused ion beam microscope for material and device characterization. Students use these newly-acquired skills in research projects mentored by faculty from the departments of Mechanical and Materials Engineering, Electrical and Computer Engineering, Physics, Chemistry, Biology, and Geology. It is highly anticipated that REU participants leave the summer program with a quintessential skill (electron and ion microscopy) applicable to all disciplines and a broader perspective of the impact of research on their higher education and career choices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This REU Site program has operated successfully for more than twenty-one years (2001-2023), fostering significant participation from women, minorities, and student veterans of the US Armed Forces. This program, integrating faculty mentorship, cutting-edge research projects, and carefully designed training activities, has made substantial strides toward building the nation’s workforce and leadership in science and engineering. By bringing together undergraduates from diverse disciplines, ethnic backgrounds, and institutions, the program has provided invaluable hands-on research experiences and facilitated the improvement of problem-solving skills among its participants.

This REU site has offered a diverse set of research projects for the REU participants under the theme of electron microscopy for multidisciplinary applications. Throughout the concentrated summer program, participants engage in independent research, attend research-skill workshops, and complete an electron microscopy and microanalysis short course. These skills are refined through engaging research projects selected for their relevance to microscopy. All the research faculty mentors have well-equipped labs where the REU participants work on their own projects and alongside graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. Working with a team of researchers who serve as teammates, graduate mentors, and immediate supervisors makes REU research projects more approachable for someone who is new to research. These projects provide REU students with the opportunity to work as part of a larger team toward a common goal and observe the intersection and overlapping of different research styles, and sometimes, different fields. Representative REU students were selected to attend conferences in engineering and research fields during the summer, allowing them to network with the scientists and engineers who are pushing research forward. These opportunities enabled the REU students to realize that modern-day research involves multidisciplinary approaches, which, in turn, motivates them to equip themselves with multidisciplinary knowledge.

The program's exit survey reports by the REU participants suggest that they have greatly benefited from the well-designed training activities of this site, which include lab skill coaching, technical writing, public speaking, conference presentation, journal submission, in addition to their focused summer research projects. The improved confidence has empowered the REU participants to pursue career goals in science and engineering. 

Here are examples of participants' reflections in their survey reports:

"I learned my love and passion for the life and routine of research. I learned so much about how research works and how it's about using what you have, to learn more about what you strive to know. My goal to pursue research has grown. I plan to continue down the research path in my future."

"I gained hands-on experience using each step of the scientific method. In the setting I was in, I was allowed to make and learn from my mistakes which helped me become more confident with trying new ideas while conducting research."

"I feel as though I gained a lot from the summer REU. I gained a lot more knowledge on experimental design, how to reach out to grad programs, how to write a research paper, and how to effectively search for relevant articles. I also gained confidence in my abilities in the lab. My perspective has somewhat changed in that I learned more about what going into industry research could look like and what continuing in academia could look like, which just made me realize that the two paths are a lot more interchangeable than I previously thought and those careers could carry quite a bit of overlap in terms of faculty/industry partnerships."

Renewed seven times from 2001 to 2023, this REU site has served over 260 total participants. A survey conducted before the COVID-19 pandemic indicated that over 90% of participants were either attending graduate school (82%), working in a science or engineering field, or planning to pursue graduate studies following their undergraduate degree. The REU participants' contributions were documented in more than 90 publications, with REU students serving as co-authors and several as first authors. The twenty-year legacy of this REU site means that many of the early REU students have now achieved PhD degrees, are working in research institutions mentoring the next generation of students or are working for high-tech companies across the country. Many other REU alumni have won fellowships or research assistantships in graduate schools as they continue their education. Outreach to K–12 students offered by this REU site in collaboration with Saturday Academy, enabled more than two dozen high school students to join in the REU training activities, served as summer interns in REU faculty advisors’ labs, worked alongside REU students. All these high school interns have progressed to colleagues and universities after their high school graduation. Partnerships with local high-tech companies have facilitated visits for REU participants through field trips. Inviting engineers and scientists from these companies to share their experiences have enriched REU participants’ direct knowledge about the high-tech industry and engineering fields.
